error.signature: error TS2786: 'X' cannot be used as a JSX component. Its return type 'ReactNode' is not a valid JSX element.
error.regex: TS2786: '([\w]+)' cannot be used as a JSX component

verdict.summary: Almost always caused by multiple versions of @types/react in the dependency tree. Different packages depend on different @types/react versions, causing conflicting JSX element type definitions.

dead_ends.action: Changing the component's return type to JSX.Element
dead_ends.why_fails: JSX.Element is overly restrictive â€” it breaks when the component returns null, a string, or a fragment. The real issue is usually a @types/react version mismatch between dependencies, not the return type annotation.
dead_ends.common_misconception: The return type is the problem, when the real issue is that two @types/react versions define incompatible JSX.Element types.

dead_ends.why_fails: Suppresses the error at each call site but does not fix the root cause. Creates N error suppressions that must be maintained and removed later. Breaks type checking for all props on those components.
dead_ends.common_misconception: Error suppression is a fix rather than a workaround.

dead_ends.action: Wrapping the component with React.createElement instead of JSX
dead_ends.why_fails: React.createElement has the same type constraints as JSX syntax. The version mismatch still causes type errors; it just changes the error message from TS2786 to a different TS error code.
dead_ends.common_misconception: JSX is assumed to have different type checking than createElement.

workarounds.action: Force a single @types/react version with resolutions or overrides
workarounds.how: In package.json, add: for npm: "overrides": { "@types/react": "^18.2.0" }, for yarn: "resolutions": { "@types/react": "^18.2.0" }, for pnpm: "pnpm": { "overrides": { "@types/react": "^18.2.0" } }. Then rm -rf node_modules && npm install.
workarounds.tradeoff: All dependencies must work with the forced version

workarounds.action: Stop using React.FC and type return as React.ReactElement | null
workarounds.how: React.FC return type changed between @types/react 17 and 18. Direct function typing is more stable: function MyComponent(props: Props): React.ReactElement | null { ... }. This avoids the FC type definition conflict.

workarounds.action: Add a wrapper component with explicit typing for library components
workarounds.how: If the component is from a library with an old @types/react: const Wrapped: React.FC<Props> = (props) => <LibComponent {...props} />; The wrapper component uses your local @types/react, resolving the mismatch.
workarounds.tradeoff: Adds wrapper indirection for each affected library component

frequently_confused_with.distinction: TS2786 is specific to JSX component usage and typically caused by @types/react version conflicts. TS2322 is a general type assignment error that can occur in any context.
